mental_health_myths.fact: Mental health conditions are very common. 1 in 4 people will experience mental health issues at some point in their lives. It's more common than you think.

mental_health_myths.myth: Mental illness is a sign of weakness
mental_health_myths.fact: Mental health conditions are medical conditions, not character flaws. They can affect anyone, regardless of strength, intelligence, or willpower.

mental_health_myths.myth: People with mental illness are dangerous
mental_health_myths.fact: People with mental health conditions are far more likely to be victims of violence than perpetrators. Most people with mental illness are not violent.

mental_health_myths.myth: Mental health problems can be overcome by willpower alone
mental_health_myths.fact: While positive thinking helps, mental health conditions often require professional treatment, medication, therapy, or a combination of approaches.
Therapy is for anyone who wants to improve their mental health, cope with stress, or work through life's challenges. It's a normal and healthy choice.
Antidepressants treat symptoms of depression and anxiety. They don't change your fundamental personality - they help you return to your normal self.

mental_health_myths.myth: Once you start medication, you have to take it forever
mental_health_myths.fact: Many people take medication for a limited time and then taper off under medical supervision. The duration depends on individual needs.
Mental health conditions can affect people of all ages, including children and teenagers. Early intervention is important.

mental_health_myths.myth: Talking about mental health makes it worse
mental_health_myths.fact: Talking about mental health reduces stigma and helps people get the support they need. It often makes things better, not worse.

mental_health_myths.myth: Mental health days are just excuses to be lazy
mental_health_myths.fact: Mental health days are legitimate and necessary for maintaining overall well-being, just like physical health days for illness.

depression_myths.fact: Depression is a serious medical condition that affects mood, thoughts, physical health, and behavior. It's more than just temporary sadness.
Depression is a chemical imbalance in the brain, not a reflection of your character or gratitude level.
Exercise is helpful and can improve mood, but severe depression usually requires professional treatment in addition to lifestyle changes.

depression_myths.myth: If you're depressed, you should just 'snap out of it'
depression_myths.fact: Depression can't be overcome by willpower alone. It requires understanding, support, and often professional treatment.

anxiety_myths.myth: Anxiety is just worrying too much
anxiety_myths.fact: Anxiety disorders involve intense, persistent worry that interferes with daily life and can include physical symptoms like rapid heartbeat and sweating.
Most anxiety medications are not addictive when taken as prescribed. Some anti-anxiety medications can be habit-forming if misused.

anxiety_myths.myth: Avoiding anxiety triggers is the best solution
anxiety_myths.fact: While some avoidance is necessary, learning to face fears gradually (exposure therapy) is often the most effective long-term solution.

student_myths.myth: Mental health issues are normal for students
student_myths.fact: While stress is common, severe mental health issues are not 'normal' and should be addressed professionally.

student_myths.myth: Taking time off for mental health will ruin your academic record
student_myths.fact: Most universities have policies for medical leave, and prioritizing mental health often leads to better academic performance.

student_myths.myth: Only weak students struggle with mental health
student_myths.fact: Mental health challenges affect students at all academic levels and from all backgrounds.

hindi_myths.myth: मानसिक बीमारी कमजोरी का संकेत है
hindi_myths.fact: मानसिक स्वास्थ्य स्थितियां चिकित्सा स्थितियां हैं, न कि चरित्र की कमियां। ये किसी भी व्यक्ति को प्रभावित कर सकती हैं।

hindi_myths.myth: मानसिक बीमारी वाले लोग खतरनाक होते हैं
hindi_myths.fact: मानसिक स्वास्थ्य स्थितियों वाले लोग हिंसा के पीड़ित होने की अधिक संभावना रखते हैं, न कि अपराधी। ज्यादातर लोग हिंसक नहीं होते।

hindi_myths.myth: दवा शुरू करने के बाद इसे हमेशा लेना पड़ता है
hindi_myths.fact: कई लोग सीमित समय के लिए दवा लेते हैं और फिर चिकित्सकीय पर्यवेक्षण में इसे कम करते हैं। अवधि व्यक्तिगत आवश्यकताओं पर निर्भर करती है।

hindi_myths.myth: मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के बारे में बात करना इसे बदतर बना देता है
hindi_myths.fact: मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के बारे में बात करना कलंक को कम करती है और लोगों को आवश्यक सहायता मिलने में मदद करती है।
